statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Matt Mobley had 24 points, 10 rebounds and six assists, Jaylen Adams scored 22 points and St. Bonaventure beat Pepperdine 89-63 in the final game of the Lone Star Showcase on Wednesday night.
article.headline: St. Bonaventure beats Pepperdine 89-63 in Lone Star Showcase
article.linkText: St. Bonaventure beats Pepperdine 89-63 in Lone Star Showcase
article.story: CEDAR PARK, Texas -- Matt Mobley had 24 points, 10 rebounds and six assists, Jaylen Adams scored 22 points and St. Bonaventure beat Pepperdine 89-63 in the final game of the Lone Star Showcase on Wednesday night. Mobley made five 3-pointers and Adams hit four as St. Bonaventure was 12 of 24. The Bonnies led 42-40 at halftime and limited Pepperdine to 23 second-half points. St. Bonaventure took control after going on an 8-0 run for a 61-48 lead and they led by double figures the rest of the way. Denzel Gregg and Idris Taqqee added 10 points apiece for St. Bonaventure (3-2), which made 51 percent from the field. It was Mobley's first double-double of the season. The Bonnies finished the tournament with a 2-1 mark. Lamond Murray Jr. made five 3-pointers and scored 24 points for Pepperdine (4-2). He was 5 of 8 from distance but just 6 of 17 overall. Jeremy Major and Craig LeCesne each added 10 points.
